subject: Re: Tesing-testing
author: Fiona Broome
full_text:
Hi Draiga,

You're not butting in at all!  

You're also correct:  Unless we have a satellite way out there that sees things sooner, all of our data is based on what we perceive, and how long that information/image takes to get to a point where we (or our devices) can perceive it.

So, when we talk about something happening two weeks ago -- but we're talking about something, say, 100 light years away -- we're usually talking about us _seeing it happen_ two weeks ago.

In actual fact, it happened about a hundred years ago.  We're only now seeing it.

Wormholes may provide us with exceptions.  Black holes may be deterrents in how quickly (if ever) we perceive things here.

It's wild stuff, isn't it!  I often call this "pretzel logic" because I so often have to wrap my brain into (illogical?) twists so this makes sense to me.

Most of the time, I have to pause and think it through, or sketch it on paper so I have a visual understanding of the concepts.

Cheerfully,
Fiona

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "draiga1" <blackwing@...> wrote:

> Fiona,
> 
> Sorry to butt in, but I'm curious. If this is happening 500 Light Years away from us, doesn't that mean it will be visible to us in 500 years? I know that there is a delay with sound such as thunder, then the delay before an individual hears it depending on how far they are from where the sound originated. Wouldn't it be the same with light?
